segments.text: The obvious response is 296 pages above.
I'm looking for a feature that... The next thing is, the next question you get from stupid interviewers is, no, I mean, what's the story?
If it took me 296 pages to tell it in the book, in print, over 100,000 words, well over.
How do you think I'm going to tell it to you in a paragraph?
No, my job is to come up with something.
Exactly.
And the tour for me is a waste of time.
The only time I go to a sign in one of those circuses in the bookstores,
I don't care if the guy signs the book.
I want to know if the book's any good.
I'm going to buy it.
If by some chance I, by some free arrangement, expect to encounter them, I'll probably bring the book along and then sign it.
Because I do like that.
But if I don't, it won't bother me.
I may drop them a line and say, nice book.
And if it isn't a nice book, I'll keep my mouth shut.
They persist in setting me up for these things.
And they did it in 1992.
And I said after that,
disaster, which would have been greater had I not canceled the West Coast and the Middle West.
I'm not going to do this anymore.
It doesn't work.
Yes, it does not work.

And it costs a lot of money.

It prevents me from writing.

Do you have one?
No, I don't.
I write in my study.
I have to have my surroundings and my reference books and all the rest of it around me.

to establish this pest.

I said, why the hell do you think I have the boat?
To get away from the writing.
So I won't work.
And the reason I have the boat instead of something else is because sailing is the only thing I like to do so well when I'll do it instead of writing.
And it will take your mind to that brief moment away from Brighton.
Oh, it's more than a brief moment.
Or whatever.
We went to Buzzards Bay and Narragansk Bay this summer.
We had a glorious time.
We put about 320 miles in that vessel.
It was just great.
It was wonderful.
And the thing about sailing is the thing.
I can't stand something in which you're not thinking.
Boring, whatever it is.
I don't want to watch the grass grow.
I don't want to watch somebody else sail.
I'm sailing.
That's true.
How do you like hope?
Jack McCray is the best editor I've ever had.
Far or none.
Jack knows when he reads my manuscript, when I finally let him see it, when I finally coyly show him a bit of a thing, he knows exactly what's wrong with it.
And he knows exactly how to fix it.
And he's half right.
He knows what's wrong with it.
He has no idea how to fix it.
And once he tells me what's wrong with it, you fix it.
I know how to fix it.
But do you have a sense maybe that you know what's wrong with it and he's just validating it?
No, I don't.
He's validating it?
No, I don't.
I was going to say almost always.
Always.

Of course, that's right.
